It stars Daniel Day-Lewis as Lincoln who won the U.S Presidential election in 1865, Sally Field as Ellen Johnson, who was a prominent lawyer at that time, James Spader as Henry Stowe, who was a prominent abolitionist at that time, and John Hannah as John C. Calhoun, who was a prominent conservative political theorist at that time.
The film received critical acclaim, winning eight Academy Awards including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor in a Leading Role Daniel Day-Lewis, Best Actor in a Supporting Role James Spader, Best Original Screenplay Christopher Nolan and Best Film Color William Fordham Cottrell. Additionally, it was nominated for seven other Academy Awards including Best Art Direction Andrew Mckee, Best Costume Design Collette Barton, Best Film Editing Paul Thomas Anderson, Best Sound Michael Hedges, Best Visual Effects Peter Jackson.
The film grossed $452 million worldwide and became one of the highest-grossing films of all time. It is also considered as one of the greatest films ever made by many people including Roger Ebert who wrote in Chicago Sun-Times that "Lincoln" is a movie about an idea, not a movie about an act.
